metadata.title: Nano-sized metal organic framework to improve the structural properties and desalination performance of thin film composite forward osmosis membrane

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Membrane Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/memsci
Nano-sized metal organic framework to improve the structural properties and desalination performance of thin film composite forward osmosis membrane
Alireza Zirehpoura, Ahmad Rahimpoura,⁎, Mathias Ulbrichtb,⁎
a Department of Chemical Engineering, Babol Noushirvani University of Technology, Shariati Ave., Babol, Iran b Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie II, Universität Duisburg-Essen, 45117 Essen, Germany
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nanoparticle Metal-organic framework Forward osmosis Thin-film nanocomposite membrane Desalination
A B S T R A C T
In the present study, nano-sized metal-organic framework (MOF) particles consisting of silver (I) and 1,3,5- benzene tricarboxylic acid were synthesized and applied to improve the structural properties as well as desalination performance of thin-film composite (TFC) forward osmosis (FO) membranes. The MOF nanocrystals were incorporated into the polyamide layer of membranes through interfacial polymerization. Characterizations by Field emission scanning electron microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy enabled the detection of MOF nanocrystals within the selective layer of the resultant membranes. The MOF incorporation led to changes of the membrane active layer in terms of hydrophilicity and transport properties, without detrimental effects on the layer selectivity. These features enhanced pure water permeability of the membranes to 129%, which was provided through 0.04% MOF loading of the organic phase during interfacial polymerization. As a result, the modified membrane exhibited an enhanced FO seawater desalination performance in comparison with the control membrane. The performance stability of TFC membrane was also improved by presence of MOF in active layer (as seen by a water flux decline of about 7% for modified membrane against about 18% for unmodified membrane when tested with real seawater). This study demonstrates the potential of MOF particles to enhance desalination performance of TFC membranes in FO systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The continuous growth of the world population increases the water demand, leading to the rising use of alternative water sources such as desalination of seawater [1]. Technologies based on membrane processes provide an important opportunity for addressing the general water crisis by enabling water supply from different resources. Forward osmosis (FO), a high water recovery and low cost membrane-based technology, has a unique capability in desalination [2] and wastewater treatment [3–5]. Compared to pressure-driven membrane technologies, the lack of applied hydraulic pressure has been considered as advantage of FO. As a result, there are several unique benefits such as low energy consumption and low membrane fouling, as well as a high water recovery ratio [6–12]. The membrane used in FO desalination process plays the most important role as it determines the overall performance of the process. Therefore, high-performance FO membranes are highly desired. These membranes should provide a superior productivity and selectivity [13,14]. Thin film composite (TFC) mem-
branes have been used predominantly as osmotic membranes in water and energy applications because of their high intrinsic water permeability and selectivity [15–19]. Modification of TFC membranes by incorporating nanomaterials is a promising approach to further improve the membrane properties. In this regard, there are two types of strategies. A more common strategy for this purpose is to improve the substrate layer properties of TFC FO membrane, such as increasing hydrophilicity and porosity, and optimizing the pore structure, and hence reducing internal concentration polarization (ICP) [20–23]. Another approach is to improve thin active layer properties of TFC membranes. Notably, thin-film nanocomposite (TFN) membranes were developed via incorporating nanoparticles in the selective layer [24]. Various types of nanomaterials have been studied comprising zeolite, silica, carbon nanotubes, pure metals and metal oxides to improve the TFN membranes properties [25–30]. For instance, hydrophilic and negatively charged zeolite nanoparticles were loaded in the polyamide layer during interfacial polymerization process. The modification considerably enhanced the permeability and surface properties of the

resultant membrane [24,28]. Silica nanoparticles were also used in TFC membrane for application in water purification, presenting an improved performance compared to control membrane [31,32]. Despite this progress, there is still a major problem, as incorporating nanomaterials in the membrane active layer can cause detrimental effects on the membrane selectivity [33–35].
In recent years, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), consisting of metal ions coordinated to organic ligands as linkers, have been studied as new category of organic/inorganic hybrid materials with tailored pore structure. The organic linkers present in MOFs structure provide also a better affinity between MOF and organic polymers, compared with purely inorganic compounds as additive. That had already been utilized for preparation of advanced mixed matrix membranes [36– 38]. The good compatibility between the two phases has been related to the formation of non-covalent bonds, such as hydrogen bonds, or even covalent bonds when the MOF-polymer composite is formed via in situ polymerization [38]. This feature provides an opportunity for improving the membrane active layer properties without adverse effects on its selectivity. As a result, incorporating MOFs in the active layer of TFC membranes offers to promise advantages over other nanostructured materials.
This study aims to investigate the use of MOF nanocrystals, consisting of silver (I) and 1,3,5-benzene tricarboxylic acid (3HBTC), for improving FO desalination performance of TFC membranes. Due to the organic linker in the MOF nanocrystals framework there should be a good compatibility with the aromatic polyamide layer because hydrogen bonding between 3HBTC and the polyamide is favored and even the formation of amide bonds between MOF and polyamide is possible during in situ cross-linking polycondensation. Therefore, the membrane active layer should be improved without detrimental effects on the layer selectivity. To the authors' knowledge, this is the first research incorporating MOF nanocrystals in the thin polyamide layer of TFC membranes to improve FO desalination performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. MOF preparation
sections.text: MOF nanocrystals were synthesized via ultrasonic irradiation of the reaction mixture at a frequency of 24 kHz (Hielscher UP400s, Germany) for a reaction time of 60 min. In a typical synthesis, silver nitrate (AgNO3, 1g) was dissolved in 40 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and mixed with 40 mL solution of 3HBTC (1g) in DMF. The output and pulse of ultrasonic waves were kept to be 80 W and 0.6, respectively. Subsequently, the product was centrifuged, and the precipitate was washed with a mixture of water and ethanol (1:1) and subsequently dried in an oven for 24 h at 60 °C. The obtained product was stored in a sealed container before use.

sections.heading: 2.2. FO membranes preparation and characterization
sections.text:
The substrate membrane were fabricated using a dope solution containing 14 wt% polyethersulfone (PES) and 1 wt% polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) dissolved in DMF. The dope solution was spread onto a flat glass using casting knife set to obtain a thickness of 100 µm. The casted film was immersed into a water container at 25 °C to initiate phase inversion. The resulting PES substrates were kept in deionized (DI) water before use.
Thin film polyamide layer of FO membranes was made via interfacial polymerization (IP) process on the PES substrates. The PES substrates were dipped in a 2.0 wt% m-phenylendiamine (MPD) solution in water for 2 min. An air knife was used to remove the surplus MPD solution from the substrate surface. Then the MPD-soaked substrates were immersed in a 0.1 wt/v% trimesoylchloride (TMC) solution in n-hexane (30 s). The reaction between MPD and TMC at the interface of the two immiscible solutions formed a nanoscale polyamide
barrier layer on the PES substrates. Afterwards, the membranes were immediately transferred to an oven (80 °C) for five minutes. The resultant TFC membranes were kept in DI water before use. The previously synthesized MOF nanocrystals were loaded within the organic solution used for fabrication of polyamide layer by IP to yield thin-film nanocomposite (TFN) membranes. Three different concentrations of MOF nanocrystals (0.02, 0.04 and 0.08 wt/v%) were loaded in the TMC in n-hexane solution and dispersed by ultrasonicating for 30 min. The prepared membranes are denoted as TFC (the control membrane without MOF), TFN-0.02 (membrane with nominal loading of 0.02% MOF nanocrystals), TFN-0.04 (nominal loading 0.04%) and TFN-0.08 (nominal loading 0.08%).
Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), with the instrument TESCAN MIRA3 equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) unit, was used to characterize the cross section and top surface morphologies and chemical compositions of the membranes. The samples were coated with a uniform gold layer before observation. Also, atomic force microscopy (AFM), with the instrument Nanosurf EasyScan II, was used to investigate the surface morphology of the prepared membranes. The most common surface roughness parameters of the membranes, including the roughness average (Ra), the root mean square roughness (Rq) and the peak to valley roughness (Rm), were calculated (for definitions and details see Supplementary information).
A contact angle instrument (G10, KRUESS) and water as test liquid were used to examine five random spots on the membrane surface in terms of hydrophilicity. The experimental error was considered via reporting the average values.
The elemental composition of the polyamide layer was identified by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an instrument from Bestec, Germany, and an Al Kα X-ray source. The survey and high resolution spectra were collected with passing energy of 160 eV and 20 eV, respectively. The measured binding energies were calibrated with respect to C1s hydrocarbon signal at 284.6 eV. The element ratio of O/N was used to estimate the cross-linking degree of the polyamide layer, using the following equations [39]:

where m and n are the relative fractions of cross-linked part and linear part, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3. Transport properties and FO performance assessment
sections.text:
The FO water flux and reverse solute flux as the most common performance indicators for FO membranes were measured via a labscale FO setup. The setup contained a membrane test cell with an effective area of 30 cm2. Two diaphragm pumps circulated feed solution (FS) and draw solution (DS) on both sides of the cell. The setup was equipped with two adjustable flow meters to set a crossflow velocity of 21 cm/s in both the FS and DS channels. The FO setup had controllers to monitor and fix temperature of the FS and DS. DI water was used as FS in the experiments. In order to provide the osmotic gradient, different concentrations of NaCl solution (0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2 M) were used as DS. A balance monitored the weight change of FS at 60 s intervals to measure the FO water flux (Jw), calculated using the following equation:

sections.heading: 3.1. MOF nanocrystals characterization
sections.text:
Many different MOF structures have been reported in the literature. One prominent combination of building blocks is the use of metal ions as node and the organic carboxylic acid 3HBTC as linker. 3HTBC is attractive in the context of this study because it is a derivative of the cross-linker used for polyamide synthesis. To the author's knowledge, silver (I) had not yet been used in combination with 3HBTC. The synthesis protocol had been adapted from typical conditions in literature [41], and the material had been obtained in good yield (54% based on silver nitrate).
The MOF nanomaterial was characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), EDX and X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) as presented in Fig. 1. Moreover, the nanocrystal size distribution in n-hexane solution was investigated using dynamic light scattering (DLS) analysis. The instruments and methods are described in the Supplementary information (SI). The TEM image shows that the prepared MOF nanocrystals have a rod-shaped morphology. The MOF rods are around 30 nm in diameter and have much larger length (Fig. 1a). The DLS analysis indicated that the hydrodynamic diameter distribution of MOF nanoparticles is approximately Gaussian, with
number-based and z-average average values of about 33 nm and 85 nm, respectively (Fig. 1b). Hence, the length of the MOF nanorods was obviously shortened after sonicating their dispersion in hexane. These results can prove the claim that the nanomaterial is small enough so that its integration in the membrane active layer will not cause defects. As shown in Fig. 1c, the XRD pattern of the MOF nanocrystals displays three characteristic peaks for silver: Ag (111), Ag (200) and Ag (220) [26,42]. In addition, there are other sharp and intense peaks at 6.6°, 9.8°, 11.2° and 13.1°. The crystal structure of this phase had not been solved, and, as mentioned above, no reference from literature is available. The EDX analysis shows four peaks attributed to carbon, oxygen and two silver species (Ag Lα and Ag Lβ) (Fig. 1d), indicating participation of both organic and inorganic phases in the structure. Considering the information on overall composition, it is plausible to attribute this pattern to MOF nanocrystals.
The BET results presented in SI (Fig. S1 and Table S1) implied that the synthesized nanomaterial has a relatively small pore volume. The specific surface area measured by BET analysis was about 170 m2/g. This relatively low value may also indicate that the synthesized structure consists of a porous (MOF) and a non-porous (Ag) phase. However, this material is not supposed to be used in gas absorption applications so that a very high specific surface area is not mandatory.

sections.heading: 3.2. Membrane characterization
sections.text:
Top surface FE-SEM images of the TFC and TFN membranes taken using different detectors are shown in Fig. 2. The left-side images show the surface of the membranes using common secondary electron detector, while the right-side images present data using backscattered electron mode. The bright areas in each of the modes have a different meaning. The bright areas in the secondary mode denote projections or hills on the sample surface. In the backscattered electron imaging mode, the bright areas indicate high atomic weight elements on the
membrane surface. As can be seen from Fig. 2, loading a minimum amount of MOF nanomaterial in the TMC in n-hexane solution resulted in the appearance of bright spots on the surface of TFN-0.02 membrane (Fig. 2b, right-side). Higher loadings of the MOF nanocrystals produced higher density of the spots on the surface of corresponding membranes (Fig. 2c and d). These shiny spots are attributed to silver as characteristic element of the MOF nanocrystals used. This assignment is reasonable because heavy metals (such as silver in this case) backscatter electrons more strongly than light elements (such as carbon, nitrogen and oxygen in the polyamide layer), and hence appear
brighter in the image [43,44]. Fig. 3 shows higher magnification FE-SEM images of the TFN-0.08 membrane surface. The MOF nanocrystals seem to be surrounded by the thin-film polyamide matrix (blue arrows), as a result of good compatibility between the MOF nanocrystals and the polyamide network. Hence, the properties of both phases quite matched, and no gaps were observed between them. EDX spectra recognized silver in different bright areas on the TFN-0.08 surface associated with MOF nanocrystals location (Fig. 3). This result can confirm the results of FESEM observation and prove existence of the nanocrystals in the thin
selective layer of the TFN membranes. The polyamide active layers of the FO membranes were investigated through XPS analysis (~10 nm sampling depth) and the results are summarized in Table 1. The XPS detected silver in the TFN-0.08 membrane, demonstrating the existence of the MOF nanocrystals in the top 10 nm below the outer membrane surface.
The cross-linking degree of the polyamide layer was calculated from the element ratios of C/N (atomic concentrations of carbon and nitrogen) and O/N (atomic concentrations of oxygen and nitrogen) obtained from XPS analyses. Results showed that loading the MOF nanocrystals into the polyamide layer increased both O/N and C/N ratios for the TFN membranes. However, the organic linker of MOF possesses also abundant carbon and oxygen atoms, and hence the element ratio of O/N and C/N may not be exactly reflecting the crosslinking degree of the polyamide layer. Therefore, the oxygen and carbon contents added by the MOF organic linker were estimated using atomic concentrations determined from MOF EDX analysis (Fig. 1d). This estimation allows one to determine how much of the increase in the O/N and C/N ratio is the result of a lower cross-linking degree and what fraction is due to the existence of additional oxygen and carbon by presence of MOF. Table 1 shows two types of O/N and C/N ratios (α and β). The ratios symbolized by α were determined directly from the XPS results, whereas the ratios represented by β were estimated after excluding the carbon and oxygen contents added by
presence of MOF. As can be seen from Table 1, the TFC membrane had around 97% polyamide cross-linking degree, while loading the MOF nanocrystals increased both the O/N and C/N ratios of the TFN membrane to 1.08 and 7.2 (ratios denoted by β), respectively, indicating that the polyamide cross-linking degree was reduced to 88%.
High-resolution oxygen (1s) spectra of the TFC and TFN membranes, presented in Fig. 4, showed two peaks at 530.8 eV and 532.4 eV (Fig. 4a and b), illustrating the presence of two types of oxygen in the selective layer. The former intense peak is ascribed to oxygen in NC˭O*/O-C˭O* groups and the latter corresponds to oxygen in O*-C˭O groups [45–47]. The TFN membrane had an additional peak at 531.7 eV (Fig. 4b), which is attributed to oxygen in C-O*-H groups [48]. This exclusive peak is attributed to the carboxylic acid groups of MOF nanocrystals. This is a very important result. The verification of the silver content in the polyamide of TFN membrane could in principle also be due to incorporation of silver nanoparticles which are one fraction of the nanomaterial (cf. Fig. 1b and related discussion above), but the identification of the organic building block of the MOF provides very strong evidence for its incorporation in the membrane selective layer.
Fig. 5 compares surface hydrophilicity and roughness of the membranes. With increasing the MOF loading, the water contact angle of the resulting membranes displayed a decreasing trend, demonstrating that the surface of TFN membranes became more hydrophilic (Fig. 5a). This can again be related to the functionality of the organic building block of the MOF, featuring carboxylic acid groups (their presence as “dangling” groups on the surface of the nanocrystals is plausible). The AFM results indicated no considerable alteration in surface roughness of the membranes after incorporating MOF nanocrystals (Fig. 5b). This indicates that the integration of the inorganicorganic nanomaterial had occurred without larger impact on the matrix polymer surface topography and layer morphology. This may be related to the good compatibility between both materials. All characterization results suggested that loading MOF nanocrystals modified the TFN membranes in terms of physiochemical properties of the polyamide layer. These alterations may change the transport properties and FO performance of the resultant membranes.
It should be noted that no absolute value for the MOF content in the
active layer could be obtained because of the very complicated analytical task considering the complex composite structure. However, it is obvious that the characterizations reveal that an increase of nanomaterial fraction used during synthesis of the active layer lead to a systematic change of barrier layer properties (cf. Figs. 2 and 5a). Hence, it is expected that the nominal MOF content should also have an impact on the membrane properties.

sections.heading: 3.3. Membrane transport parameters and performance in FO process
sections.text:
Transport parameters of the membranes including water (A) and solute (B) permeability were calculated via the protocol by Tiraferri et al. [40]. Fig. 6 shows the corresponding results. Additional parameters obtained from the protocol as well as measured salt rejections are presented in the SI (Table S2). Incorporating MOF nanocrystals in the TFN membranes' polyamide layer caused an increasing trend in their water permeability. Loading 0.04% wt. of MOF nanocrystals resulted in a 129% enhancement in the membrane water permeability compared to control TFC membrane. An additional loading of MOF nanocrystals yielded the highest water permeability of 7.1 L/m2 h bar by the TFN-0.08 membrane (238% higher than that of the TFC
membrane), but at the same time with a detrimental influence on the membrane selectivity. This alteration increased the B value of TFN0.08 membrane almost fourfold and twofold compared to the TFC and TFN-0.04 membranes, respectively. The solute permeability/water permeability ratio (B/A ratio) is an important parameter that indicates FO membrane selectivity. Generally, small B/A ratio represents a better selectivity and is desired in FO systems [49,50].
The B/A ratios of the TFN-0.02 and TFN-0.04 membranes were slightly smaller than that of the TFC membrane (Table S2). These observations indicate that the increase of solute permeability is lower than that of water permeability. However, the TFN-0.08 membrane had the highest B/A ratio among all membranes. These results clearly suggest that an appropriate, i.e. not too high, loading of the MOF nanocrystals provides a lower transport resistance in the TFN membranes' active layer, while preserving its permeation selectivity.
In principle, incorporating the MOF nanocrystals offers a number of advantages to provide a lower transport resistance in the selective layer of TFN membranes. Loading MOF nanocrystals in TMC organic solution affects the IP process resulting in a disrupted polymer chain packing [51]. That this effect may be responsible for the performance improvement is supported by the observed lower cross linking degree in the selective layer of the TFN membrane compared to the TFC membrane, as shown by the XPS results (cf. Table 1). However, a too high MOF fraction has apparently a detrimental influence on selective layer integrity and hence selectivity. Additionally, the more hydrophilic surface of the TFN membranes as a result of MOF loading can attract water molecules and facilitate their transport through the barrier layer.
The MOF nanocrystals improved FO performance of the membranes as presented in Fig. 7. FO water flux (Jw) and solute flux (Js) of the membranes were measured as the function of DS concentration in active layer facing feed solution (ALFS) orientation. Increasing the DS concentration produced an enhancement in FO water flux through the membranes (Fig. 7a) [49]. Likewise, because of a higher salt concentration gradient, Js was increased (Fig. 7b). The graph in Fig. 7a
demonstrates that a minimum loading resulted in around 18% enhancement in FO water flux of the TFN-0.02 membrane. Similarly, the FO water flux of the TFN-0.04 and TFN-0.08 membranes was improved by 27% and 55%, respectively.
This improvement can be correlated to their enhanced water permeability as well as surface hydrophilicity, which were the results of MOF nanocrystals loading. By loading MOF, reverse salt flux of the modified membranes was also increased. A too high loading of MOF produced a considerable reverse solute flux through the TFN-0.08 membrane, which is related to the solute permeability of the membrane (cf. Fig. 6).
In FO systems, specific solute flux (Js/Jw) is an important membrane performance characteristic. A lower Js/Jw ratio indicates a higher selectivity and productivity in the process [50,52,53]. Fig. 7c compares the TFC and TFN membranes in terms of the ratio. The results show a linear relationship between the Js/Jw ratio and the B/A ratio, which is in agreement with the theory of FO specific solute flux [50]. As compared to the TFC membrane, incorporating the MOF nanocrystals caused a slight reduction of the Js/Jw ratio in TFN-0.02 and TFN-0.04 membranes. This observation proves that the MOF nanocrystals improved water transport through the membranes, while the mem-
brane selectivity was retained. However, too high loading rate in the TFN-0.08 membrane reduced its selectivity and hence considerably increased the Js/Jw ratio.
Fig. 8 shows that the FO water flux of the membranes was considerably enhanced in active layer facing DS (ALDS) orientation due to the lower ICP phenomenon [54,55]. The highest FO water flux was obtained when the TFN-0.04 membrane was applied in ALDS mode (82 L/m2.h; 2 M DS).
A comparison between the TFN-0.04 membrane and other developed FO membranes published in literature has been performed, and the corresponding results are presented in the SI (Table S3). The newly prepared membrane has at least the same FO selectivity and the highest FO permeability compared to 13 relevant reports from literature. Compared to the best membrane with same selectivity [56], permeability is 1.5 times higher. This overview highlights the MOF nanocrystals’ capability to improve FO membranes significantly.

sections.heading: 3.4. Seawater desalination performance
sections.text:
Fig. 9 compares the membranes in terms of seawater desalination performance. The feed samples were taken from the Caspian Sea. The seawater composition and experimental assay conditions are provided in the SI (Section S4 and Table S3). The TFN-0.04 membrane exhibited noteworthy seawater fluxes of above 34 L/m2 h, while that flux for TFC membrane was about 27 L/m2 h (Fig. 9a). Moreover, Fig. 9b presents the performance stability of the membrane in FO seawater desalination during time.
The FO seawater desalination flux through the TFN-0.04 membrane was very stable throughout the testing period (only about 7% flux decline), whereas the TFC membrane showed about 18% reduction in water flux. The reductions in FO water flux are attributed mostly to the drop in FO driving force (DS dilution and FS concentration) and membrane fouling. As can be seen from the Fig. 9c and d, the FS was concentrated, and the DS was diluted throughout seawater desalination, indicating a gradual reduction in FO driving force. The TFN membrane exhibited higher recovery percentage (58%) than that of the TFC membrane (43%), demonstrating higher productivity of the TFN membrane (Fig. 9c).
The polyamide layer properties such as surface hydrophilicity and surface chemistry can affect the membranes fouling propensity during seawater desalination. A more hydrophilic surface was considered as an important factor to reduce the fouling propensity of a desalination membrane [57–60], providing a thin water film at the membrane surface that creates a barrier for foulant adhesion and resulting in a better antifouling property [18,61,62]. On the other hand, a high density of carboxylic acid functional groups on the polyamide layer can cause the groups to bind with Ca2+ ions from seawater, thus increasing the tendency toward inorganic fouling on the membrane surface [62,63]. The TFN-0.04 membrane had a more hydrophilic surface, but also a higher content of carboxylic acid groups compared to TFC
membrane because of incorporating the MOF nanocrystals. The former improves the TFN membrane antifouling properties (mostly for organic fouling), while the latter could cause an opposite trend (mostly for scaling). Based on the results, it can be concluded that the more hydrophilic surface of the TFN-0.04 membrane was the dominant factor compared to its higher content of carboxyl groups, resulting in a more stable water flux during seawater desalination. The results clearly suggest that MOF nanocrystals improved desalination performance of the TFN membrane, which is obvious from the enhanced and more stable water flux during seawater desalination. Considering the actual composition of the nanomaterial, with a significant fraction of silver nanoparticles (cf. Section 3.1), one might expect also an additional antibacterial activity of the membranes. Such possible dual functionality of the additive on composite membrane properties and performance should be studied in more detail in the future.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The silver-containing MOF nanocrystals with a size around 30 nm were incorporated into the nanoscale polyamide layer of composite membranes during interfacial polymerization. Structure characterization results for the membranes revealed the presence of the MOF nanocrystals in their selective layer. Incorporating MOF nanocrystals offered several advantages in the membrane properties and FO performance. The MOF nanocrystals yielded a more hydrophilic surface of the modified membranes, and provided a lower transport resistance in their selective layer, while preserving the membrane selectivity if the loading was not too high. These alterations improved desalination performance of the modified membrane which was demonstrated by an enhanced and stable water flux during seawater desalination. The opportunity of improving both FO water flux and
surface hydrophilicity of the membrane together with the absence of adverse effects on the membrane selectivity suggest MOFs as attractive materials for developing FO membranes. These conclusions demonstrate the potential of MOF compounds in improving FO membranes for seawater desalination, where both a higher and a more stable water flux are essential.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study, nano-sized metal-organic framework (MOF) particles consisting of silver (I) and 1,3,5benzene tricarboxylic acid were synthesized and applied to improve the structural properties as well as desalination performance of thin-film composite (TFC) forward osmosis (FO) membranes. The MOF nanocrystals were incorporated into the polyamide layer of membranes through interfacial polymerization. Characterizations by Field emission scanning electron microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy enabled the detection of MOF nanocrystals within the selective layer of the resultant membranes. The MOF incorporation led to changes of the membrane active layer in terms of hydrophilicity and transport properties, without detrimental effects on the layer selectivity. These features enhanced pure water permeability of the membranes to 129%, which was provided through 0.04% MOF loading of the organic phase during interfacial polymerization. As a result, the modified membrane exhibited an enhanced FO seawater desalination performance in comparison with the control membrane. The performance stability of TFC membrane was also improved by presence of MOF in active layer (as seen by a water flux decline of about 7% for modified membrane against about 18% for unmodified membrane when tested with real seawater). This study demonstrates the potential of MOF particles to enhance desalination performance of TFC membranes in FO
